title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #184: Graph Decomposition into Cycles and Edges**

**Conjecture:** Any graph on n vertices can be decomposed into O(n) edge-disjoint cycles and edges.

**Status: OPEN**

**Best Known:** O(n log* n) by Bucić-Montgomery (2022)
mathContext: The Erdős-Gallai conjecture asks for linear decomposition complexity.

title: Cycle Definition
content:
**Cycle G:**

A cycle in graph G is a sequence of ≥3 distinct vertices v₁, v₂, ..., vₖ where consecutive vertices are adjacent and vₖ is adjacent to v₁.

Cycles are the primary building blocks for decomposition.

title: Valid Decomposition
content:
**IsValidDecomposition pieces:**

A decomposition is valid if:
1. Every edge of G is covered by some piece
2. The pieces are edge-disjoint (no edge in two pieces)

This is an edge partition into cycles and isolated edges.

title: Erdős-Gallai Conjecture
content:
**ErdosGallaiConjecture:**

∃ C > 0, ∀ graphs G on n vertices: decompNumber(G) ≤ C·n

This asserts that the decomposition number grows at most linearly in n.
mathContext: The conjecture is that the constant C exists (independent of G).

title: Original Erdős-Gallai Bound
content:
**erdos_gallai_original_bound:**

O(n log n) pieces suffice for any graph on n vertices.

This was the first upper bound, proved along with the conjecture statement.

title: Lower Bound from K_{3,n-3}
content:
**lower_bound_from_bipartite:**

The complete bipartite graph K_{3,n-3} requires at least (1+c)n pieces for some c > 0.

This shows the constant in O(n) must be > 1 if the conjecture is true.
mathContext: K_{3,n-3} has 3(n-3) = 3n-9 edges, creating many short paths.

title: The Iterated Logarithm log*
content:
**logStar n:**

log*(n) = 0 if n ≤ 1, else 1 + log*(log₂(n))

This function grows INCREDIBLY slowly:
- log*(2) = 1
- log*(4) = 2
- log*(16) = 3
- log*(65536) = 4
- log*(2^65536) = 5

For any practical n, log*(n) ≤ 5.
mathContext: The inverse is the tower function: tower(5) = 2^{2^{2^{2^2}}} ≈ 10^{19728}

title: Bucić-Montgomery Bound (2022)
content:
**bucic_montgomery_bound:**

O(n log* n) pieces suffice for any graph on n vertices.

This is the current best upper bound, tantalizingly close to linear since log* is essentially constant for all practical purposes.

title: Conlon-Fox-Sudakov (2014)
content:
**conlon_fox_sudakov:**

For any ε > 0, if G has minimum degree ≥ εn, then O(n) pieces suffice.

The dense case is solved! Only sparse graphs remain for the full conjecture.

title: Summary: OPEN
content:
**erdos_184:**

**STATUS: OPEN**

**Known bounds:**
- Upper: O(n log* n) [Bucić-Montgomery 2022]
- Lower: (1+c)n [from K_{3,n-3}]
- Dense case: O(n) [CFS 2014]

The gap is tiny (log* is essentially constant) but closing it is hard.
